Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering, National Engineering Research Center for Special Separation Membrane, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing 211816, PR China. State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering, National Engineering Research Center for Special Separation Membrane Nanjing Tech University Nanjing 211816 PR China Interface interaction existed in the multicomponent determines the catalytic performance of composite catalysts. Herein, a Co3O4-LaCoO3 (Co-La) composite catalyst with strong spinel-perovskite interface interaction was successfully synthesized via a one-pot sol-gel method for the catalytic oxidation of toluene. The activity test results showed that the optimal 1Co3O4–4LaCoO3 (1Co-4La) catalyst exhibits much higher catalytic activity (T90 = 215 °C, GHSV = 50,000 h−1) than Co3O4 (T90 = 295 °C), LaCoO3 (T90 = 256 °C) and 1Co3O4/4LaCoO3 (1Co/4La) (prepared by mechanical ball-milling, T90 = 285 °C). Characterizations revealed that the strong spinel-perovskite interface interaction generated between the Co3O4 spinel and LaCoO3 perovskite in 1Co-4La facilitates the transfer of interfacial electrons, contributing to the exposure of surface active Co3+ and the enhanced oxidation ability of surface active Co3+ on 1Co-4La. In addition, the reactive lattice oxygen of surface Co3+–O on 1Co-4La effectively promotes the decomposition of toluene into CO2, enabling the low-temperature oxidation of toluene through the Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism. This work provides insight into the promotional effect of multicomponent interface interaction on enhancing catalytic performance of spinel-perovskite composite catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Co3O4-LaCoO3 Interface interaction Surface Co3+ Toluene oxidation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Catalytic oxidation is an efficient and economical technology for eliminating volatile organic compounds (VOCs), which can significantly reduce their detrimental effects on the environment and human health [1–3]. The catalyst determines the active temperature windows and application environment of catalytic oxidation technology, making it essential to develop highly efficient catalysts. Multi-component catalysts of noble metal (Pt, Rh, Pd), transition (Fe, Co, Ni, Cr, Mn and Cu) and rare earth (Ce) metal oxides generally show much higher catalytic activity than single-component catalysts in VOC decomposition [4–6]. Among multi-component catalysts, the strong interaction formed at the multi-component heterojunction interface plays a vital role in determining their catalytic activity [7,8]. Developing methods to enhance multi-component strong interaction are desired to improve the catalytic VOCs oxidation performance of catalysts. Cobalt-based oxide catalysts, especially Co3O4 spinel and LaCoO3 perovskite, have shown high catalytic activity in VOCs oxidation, and are regarded promising subsititutes for noble metal-based catalysts [9–11]. Song's group studied the promotional effect of La doping in Co3O4, and found that the formation of LaCoO3 phase may be responsible for the enhanced catalytic activity of Co3O4 in toluene oxidation [12,13]. Recently, it has been reported that the exsolution of element of cobalt in LaCoO3 can result in the formation of Co3O4, which enhances the amount of surface Co3+ on LaCoO3 and thereby improving its catalytic oxidation performance at low temperatures [14]. Selective dissolution methods via acid [15–18] or alkali [19] etching have been developed to obtain highly dispersed Co3O4 on LaCoO3 through dissolving La anions. These methods can construct Co3O4-LaCoO3 composite catalysts that show much higher catalytic oxidation acitivity than single Co3O4 spinel and LaCoO3 perovskite catalysts. However, these works leave an issues regarding understanding the effect of the interaction between Co3O4 spinel and LaCoO3 perovskite on the catalytic oxidation reaction. In this work, Co3O4-LaCoO3 composites catalysts were prepared using sol-gel and mechanical ball-milling methods to investigate the effect of interface interaction between Co3O4 and LaCoO3 on catalytic oxidation performance. The toluene oxidation performance of the prepared samples was tested and characterized using technologies such as XRD, TEM, H2-TPR, O2-TPD, TPD-MS. The goal of this work is to provide insight into the role of multi-component strong interaction at the Co3O4-LaCoO3 interface in catalytic oxidation over cobalt-based oxides and to develop highly efficient catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The LaCoO3, Co3O4 and Co3O4-LaCoO3 catalysts were prepared by a citric acid assited sol-gel method. Generally, a certain of lanthanum nitrate hexahydrate, cobalt nitrate hexahydrate and citric acid monohydrate (all the chemical reagents were purchased from Aladdin and used without any pre-treatment, the molar ratio of citric acid monohydrate/metal is set as 2) were dissolved into 50 mL deionized water. The obtained solution was heated at 100 °C to obtain a transparent sol. The sol was transformed into dried gel at 120 °C for 12 h. Finally, the LaCoO3 and the xCo3O4-yLaCoO3 (labeled as xCo-yLa, where the mole ratio of x:y varies from 1:3 to 1:5) catalysts were obtained by calcining the gel at 700 °C for 4 h. Co3O4 sample was prepared by above method without adding lanthanum nitrate hexahydrate. For comparision, 1Co3O4/4LaCoO3 (1Co/4La) samples was prepared by ball-milling method using Co3O4 and LaCoO3 as precusors. 2.2 Characterizations The phase structures of the prepared catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction measurements (XRD, MiniFlex 600, China) and Raman (Perkin-Elmer 400F). The pore size and specific surface area were recorded by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET, Micromeritics ASAP 2460), The micromorphology of the prepared catalysts is recorded by the high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM, JEOL JEM2100). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, PHI-5000C) was employed to investigate the valence state of Co and La. Electrochemical test was performed on electrochemical working station CHI 660E (Shanghai) with a three-electrode system. The Raman test was operated on a Horiba Jobin Yvon LabRAM HR instrument and the excitation wavelength is set as 532 nm. The Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS) tests were carried out by a AC impedance spectroscopy and the frequency range was set from 106 to 0.005 Hz. An automated chemisorption analyzer (AutoChem 2920) that equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was employed to conduct the temperature-programmed desorption tests (H2-TPR) in a quartz U-tube reactor. Before the experiments, all the catalysts were first pretreated at 300 °C for 60 min under inertia gas. The gas flow rate and ramping rate in the test were set as 30 mL·min–1 and 10 °C·min–1, respectively. Taking the H2-TPR test as a sample, the pretreated catalyst (0.1 g) was first purged by H2/Ar (10 vol.%) at 100 °C followed by heating to 800 °C. Toluene temperature-programmed desorption experiment was performed by combining an automated chemisorption analyzer (AutoChem 2920) and Hiden Analytical quadrupole mass spectrometer (Toluene-TPD-MS). All the catalysts were first pretreated at 300 °C for 60 min under inertia gas, and the gas flow rate and ramping rate in the test were set as 30 mL·min–1 and 10 °C·min–1, respectively. The catalyst (0.3 g) was first pretreated with toluene vapor for 60 min at 100 °C. Then the sample was heated to 800 °C under inertia atmosphere. The exhaust gasses were analyzed by TCD detector and mass spectrometer. 2.3 Toluene oxidation test The toluene oxidation test was carried out at 180–400 °C in a quartz fixed-bed reactor (i,d, 6 mm) with a catalyst depth of 0.3 mL. The gas compositions were as follows: 1000 ppm toluene, 20 vol% O2 with N2 as the balanced gas. The total gas flow rate was set as 250 mL·min−1, corresponding to a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 50,000 h−1. The concentration of toluene in the inlet and outlet was recorded by the on-line IR CO2 analyzer and the gas chromatography, which equipped with a TCD and two FID detectors (one is used for analyzing the organics and another for determining the CO2 and CO). The toluene conversion rate was calculated as follows: Toluene conversion ( % ) = ( n outlet CO 2 − n intlet CO 2 ) / 7 n toluene × 100 % Where nCO2 represents the molar flow of CO2 at the outlet (ppm), and ntoluene represents the molar flow of toluene at the inlet (ppm). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance evaluation The catalytic toluene oxidation performance of the prepared catalysts were tested, and the results are shown in Fig. 1 a. Co3O4 presents relatively poor catalytic activity at low temperatures, but toluene conversion above 90% can be obtained at temperatures above 295 °C (T90=295 °C). The LaCoO3 exhibits much higher catalytic activity than the Co3O4, and its T90 reaches only at 255 °C. The 1Co/4La catalyst displays better catalytic acitivty than Co3O4, but its toluene conversion at 240–300 °C is lower than that of LaCoO3. However, it can be easily found that xCo-yLa catalysts have much higher catalytic activity than LaCoO3, espeically for the 1Co-4La sample, among which the T90 is only about 215 °C and shows the best toluene oxidation performance within the whole testing range. These results suggest that the xCo-yLa catalysts might induce a synergistic effect between Co3O4 and LaCoO3 during one-pot preparation, which can promote the toluene oxidation. The stability performance of the 1Co-4La and 1Co/4La catalysts was separately tested at temperatures of 200 and 240 °C, respectively (Fig. 1b). The result display that the 1Co-4La maintains its toluene oxidation performance within the whole test. Remarkably, no performance degradation was observed when 5 vol.% H2O was injected, manifesting that the 1Co-4La catalyst had great water vapor resistance. However, the 1Co/4La catalyst only exhibited good stability in the absence of water vapor and its toluene oxidation performance decreased by about half with the presence of 5 vol.% H2O. While the toluene oxidation performance could be recovered when water vapor was cut off, indicating that the decreased performance was due to the competitive adsorption effect of water capor. 3.2 Phase structure analysis Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of LaCoO3, xCo-yLa, 1Co/4La and Co3O4 samples. LaCoO3 shows the diffaction peaks of standard card of hexagonal LaCoO3 perovskites (JCPDS: 25–1060), and Co3O4 presents the diffaction peaks correpsonding to the standard cubic Co3O4 spinel (JCPDS: 74–1657) (Fig. 2a). The diffraction peaks of both hexagonal LaCoO3 and cubic Co3O4 can be observed in the XRD patterns of xCo-yLa samples, indicating that the xCo-yLa samples are composed of LaCoO3 perovskites and Co3O4 spinel. With an increase in the Co/La ratio, more Co3O4 species are formed in xCo-yLa samples, leading to an increase in the peak intensity of the Co3O4 spinel phase and a decrease in the peak intensity of the LaCoO3 perovskites phase. The 1Co/4La sample also exhibts diffaction peaks of LaCoO3 perovskites and Co3O4 spinel (Fig. 2b), and the diffraction peak positions in the 1Co/4La sample are completely consistent with those of the pure LaCoO3 and Co3O4 samples, respectively (Fig. 2c). For 1Co-4La sample, however, its diffraction peak at 41.7° (belonging to the (006) face of LaCoO3 perovskites phase) shifts to a low angle, and its diffraction peak at 36.9° (belongs to the (311) face of Co3O4 spinel phase) shifts to a high angle. According to the Bragg's Law, the shift of XRD diffraction peaks can be attributed to the ion doping with different radius in comparison with bulk atoms. This result indicates that an interaction is generated in the interface between LaCoO3 and Co3O4 in 1Co-4La, leading to changes in crystal structure and spin changes in transition atoms. 3.3 Heterojunction interface analysis TEM was employed to investigate the interface of the 1Co-4La and 1Co/4La samples. Fig. 3 a0 and b0 show that 1Co-4La exhibits smaller particle size than 1Co/4La, consistent with its higher BET surface obtained in Table 1 . When viewed at a magnified magnititude (Fig. 3a 1 and b1), a distinct interface boundary is observed for the mechanical ball-milling fabricated 1Co/4La, while it is ambiguous for the one-pot prepared 1Co-4La. This implies that a strong interface interaction is generated in 1Co-4La catalyst, which can facilitate the tranfer of interfacial electrons and then synergistically catalytic oxidation of the toluene [20–22]. However, the simple mechanical mixing of Co3O4 and LaCoO3 cannot construct an effiective combination of the Co3O4 spinel and the LaCoO3 perovskite, resulting in blocked transfer of interfacial electrons and thus exhibits poor toluene oxidation performance at low temperatures. The Raman shift was employed to characterize the interface interaction of 1Co/4La and 1Co-4La. Fig. 4 a shows that the 1Co/4La exhibits three distinct peaks at 457, 503 and 664 cm–1, corresponding to the Eg, F2g and A1g symmetry of Co3O4 [23,24]. Obviously, the Raman band intensity of 1Co-4La is lower than that of 1Co/4La, and the peak corresponding to the Co3+-O vibration in octahedral sites (CoO6) shifts from 664 cm–1 to 654 cm–1. These results confirm that there is lattice distortion in 1Co-4La samples, which can be attributed to the strong interaction generated at the interface of Co3O4 and LaCoO3. The charge transfer properties between Co3O4 and LaCoO3 in the 1Co/4La and 1Co-4La samples were studied and compared using EIS and the results are shown in Fig. 4b. The EIS Nyquist plots show that the radius of the circular arc of 1Co-4La is smaller than that of the 1Co/4La, indicating that a higher charge transfer efficiency across the heterojunction interface between Co3O4 and LaCoO3 is achieved by the 1Co-4La catalyst [25–27]. Morever, 1Co/4La exhibits inferior performance than the LaCoO3, further emphasizing the significance of strong spinel-perovskite interface interaction. 3.4 Surface composition and properties analysis The valence state of Co and O in the prepared samples was analyzed and shown in Fig. 5 . The deconvolution of Co 2p shows that all the prepared samples contain Co2+ and Co3+, and the Co3+ is the dominated species (Fig. 5a). The highest ratio of Co3+/(Co2++Co3+) is obtained by the 1Co-4La sample, which is up to 62.90% (Table 1). Several studies have confirmed that Co3+ are the active species in the catalytic oxidation of toluene [28–31]. The result obtained here indicates that the strong spinel-perovskite interface interaction generated between the Co3O4 and the LaCoO3 facilitates the formation of active Co3+ in 1Co-4La, thus achieving superior toluene oxidation performance. The 1Co/4La has a Co3+/(Co2++Co3+) ratio of 49.45%, which is between pure Co3O4 (46.34%) and LaCoO3 (55.44%), in consistent with the toluene oxidation performance. These results confirm that the toluene oxidation performance is highly related to the amount of surface Co3+. The deconvoluntion of O 1 s was divided into four peaks (Fig. 5b). The peaks at low binding energy are recognized as lattice oxygen species (OL), and the peaks at higher binding energy are regarded as surface (Os-ad) and hydrated adsorbed oxygen speices (Os-OH). One can see that there is a binding energy gap of 1 ev of lattice oxygen species for the Co3O4 and LaCoO3, and the 1Co/4La and 1Co-4La samples show the combined lattice oxygen species belonging to the Co3O4 and the LaCoO3, repectively. The OS/(OS+OL) calculation results display that the 1Co-4La has the lowest OS/(OS+OL) ratio of 38.90%, while it exhibits the best toluene oxidation performance, indicating that the adsorbed oxygen species may not play a significant role in toluene oxidation. The oxidation ability of Co species on the prepared samples (Co3O4/10 means that the mass of Co3O4 used in TPR experiment are 1/10 of other samples) were studied by the H2-TPR analysis (Fig. 6 ). The Co3O4 sample exhibits a distinct peak around 300 °C, which can be ascribed to the sequence reduction of Co3+ to Co0 [32]. The LaCoO3 sample displays three peaks at about 310, 340 and 484 °C, which can be attributed to the reduction of surface Co3+ ions (Co3+ → Co2+), bulk Co3+ ions (Co3+ → Co2+) and Co2+ ions (Co2+ → Co0), respectively [15,16]. Ordinary mechanical mixing cannot induce the formation of strong interaction between multi-component, but can effectively decrease the size of nanoparticle. Therefore, 1Co/4La sample shows a H2-TPR profile combing the reduction peaks of Co3O4 and LaCoO3, and the reduction peak of Co3O4 (Co3+ → Co0) and Bul-Co3+ (Co3+ → Co2+) shifts to lower temperatures as compared with pure Co3O4 and LaCoO3 samples. 1Co-4La sample shows a similar H2-TPR profiles to LaCoO3. Compared to LaCoO3, the starting reduction temperature (SRT) and the reduction peak of Sur-Co3+ for 1Co-4La shifts to lower temperature, and its Co3+ species reduction peak area becomes larger, indicating that the strong interaction between Co3O4 and LaCoO3 induce the formation of large amount of Co3+ species with strong oxidation ability on the 1Co-4La sample. Toluene oxidation test results have proposed that the catalytic activity of samples at temperature below 300 °C follows an order of 1Co-4La > LaCoO3 > 1Co/4La > Co3O4. By comparing the H2-TPR profiles of all samples, it is found that the catalytic activity of samples may be correlation with SRT postion and reduction peak area at 150–300 °C. 3.5 Toluene adsorption and reaction analysis The toluene-TPD-MS analysis was employed to give an insight into the toluene oxidation of the prepared samples and the results are shown in Fig. 7 . From the TCD signals of toluene-TPD-MS analysis presented in Fig. 7a, broad desorption peaks could be observed at the temperature of 100–850 °C. According to the MS profiles shown in Fig. 7b–e, the desorption peak located at 100–650 °C can be assigned to the toluene desorption, while the desorption peak located at 650–850 °C is mainly attributed to the desorption of lattice oxygen. No singal of toluene can be found in the MS profiles of all samples, indicating the TCD signals detected at 100–650 °C are attributed to the products from the reaction between adsorbed toluene and surface lattice oxygen. The toluene adsorption capacity of sampels was compared based on the desorption peak area. It is found that the toluene adsorption capacity of samples follows an order of LaCoO3 > 1La-4Co ≈ 1La/4Co > Co3O4. The surface active oxygen content and toluene adsorption capacity of LaCoO3 are much higher than that of 1La-4Co, suggesting that the toluene oxidation reaction might not occurs via the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) and Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism. As shown in Fig. 7f, the CO2 desorption peak area of samples at 100–300 °C follows the sequence of 1La-4Co > LaCoO3 > 1La/4Co > Co3O4. Combined with the results of catalytic activity and H2-TPR, it can be concluded that the toluene oxidation activity of catalysts is mainly determined by the amount and reactivity of surface lattice oxygen of Co3+–O. This result is consistent with the previous reports [33,34]. Based on above discussion, it can also be concluded that the toluene oxidation reaction over 1La-4Co, LaCoO3, 1La/4Co and Co3O4 mainly processed via the Mars-van-Krevelen (MvK) route. 3.6 Possible promotional mechanism The possible promotional mechanism of toluene oxidation on 1Co-4La catalyst was proposed based on the above characterization results and discussion. As displayed in Fig. 8 , the formation of Co3O4-LaCoO3 composites during the one-pot calcination results in the formation of strong spinel-perovskite interface interaction between the Co3O4 and LaCoO3, which facilitates the exposure of active Co3+ in 1Co-4La and accelerates the charge tansfer efficiency across the heterojunction interface, thus enhancing the amount and reactivity of surface lattice oxygen of Co3+–O over 1Co-4La (TEM, Raman, EIS, XPS and H2-TPR). The reactive lattice oxygen of Co3+–O on 1Co-4La is beneficial for the decomposition of toluene into CO2, thereby promoting the low-temperature oxidation of toluene through the MvK mechanism (toluene-TPD-MS). However, there is a distinct interface for the mechanical mixed 1Co/4La, which hinders the interfacial electrons transfer and mainly depends on the catalytic properties of independent Co3O4 and LaCoO3 (for example, the decreased BET surface area), leading to relatively poor toluene oxidation performance. Thus, the 1Co-4La exhibits much superior toluene oxidation performance than the 1Co/4La. 4 Conclusion In this research, a Co3O4-LaCoO3 spinel-perovskite composite catalyst was successfully fabricated via a one-pot sol-gel approach, and used for the efficient toluene oxidation. All the prepraed xCo-yLa composite catalysts exhibit better toluene oxidation performance than the single Co3O4 and LaCoO3, and the mechanical mixed Co3O4/LaCoO3. Strikingly, the 1Co-4La shows the best toluene oxidation performance, with a T90 of only 215 °C. The TEM, Raman, EIS and H2-TPR characterization results reveal that strong spinel-perovskite interface interaction is generated between the Co3O4 and the LaCoO3, which facilitates the formation of active Co3+ and enhancing the redox capability of Co3+ cations and the interfacial charge transfer efficiency of 1Co-4La. Morever, the XPS confirms that the lattice oxygen species, not chemisorbed oxygen species, play a significantly role in the toluene oxidation. Toluene-TPD-MS analysis deems that the Mars-van-Krevelen (MvK) mechanism is more fit for the toluene oxidation on 1La-4Co. These results achieved in this research can contribute to the fundamental understanding of spinel-perovskite interface interaction and give a guidance for facile designing of high-performance spinel-perovskite composite catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Interface interaction existed in the multicomponent determines the catalytic performance of composite catalysts. Herein, a Co3O4-LaCoO3 (Co-La) composite catalyst with strong spinel-perovskite interface interaction was successfully synthesized via a one-pot sol-gel method for the catalytic oxidation of toluene. The activity test results showed that the optimal 1Co3O4–4LaCoO3 (1Co-4La) catalyst exhibits much higher catalytic activity (T90 = 215 °C, GHSV = 50,000 h−1) than Co3O4 (T90 = 295 °C), LaCoO3 (T90 = 256 °C) and 1Co3O4/4LaCoO3 (1Co/4La) (prepared by mechanical ball-milling, T90 = 285 °C). Characterizations revealed that the strong spinel-perovskite interface interaction generated between the Co3O4 spinel and LaCoO3 perovskite in 1Co-4La facilitates the transfer of interfacial electrons, contributing to the exposure of surface active Co3+ and the enhanced oxidation ability of surface active Co3+ on 1Co-4La. In addition, the reactive lattice oxygen of surface Co3+–O on 1Co-4La effectively promotes the decomposition of toluene into CO2, enabling the low-temperature oxidation of toluene through the Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism. This work provides insight into the promotional effect of multicomponent interface interaction on enhancing catalytic performance of spinel-perovskite composite catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Strong interface interaction enriched surface Co3+ cations on Co3O4-LaCoO3 composite catalyst for highly efficient toluene oxidation
